report_title: Industry Report on Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing
executive_summary: As overall manufacturing activity declines, demand for inputs like inorganic chemicals also declines. In 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic negatively influenced downstream manufacturer demand. Following the pandemic, even with the economy showing signs of recovery, the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the higher interest rate environment due to inflation-fighting have hurt manufacturing activity, supply chains and limited consumer spending growth. As a result, industry revenue has decreased at a CAGR of 0.6% to $37.8 billion over the past five years, including a projected 1.5% decline in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Inorganic chemical manufacturing is dependent on demand from downstream users
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Oil and gas production affects refining activity and the price of certain inputs of organic chemical production, which also uses inorganic chemicals. Construction is also a significant market for manufacturers because of the importance of inorganic chemicals in materials like polyvinyl chloride (PVC), dyes and paints. The industry has experienced steady consolidation to boost production capacity and build economies of scale.

Demand for some key products (e.g., chlorine and soda ash) experienced volatile demand as the US dollar's significant appreciation and a slowdown in the world economy constrained demand for domestically manufactured chemicals. Increasing production of titanium dioxide in China has led to depressed chemical prices, negatively affecting revenue and profit margin growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Profit pressures primarily affect smaller manufacturers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Russian invasion of Ukraine and the higher interest rates due to inflation-fighting have hurt manufacturing activity, supply chains and limited consumer spending growth, contributing to increasing commodity prices. Energy is one of the industry's direct production costs, which has been increasing over the past five years. Manufacturers compete on the cost to maintain profitability because all producers manufacture the same basket of products. Pandemic-related virus protection costs and decreased manufacturing capacity negatively affected profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturing of inorganic chemicals will likely resume growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industrial production index (IPI), which measures the production activity of the manufacturing, mining, oil and gas sectors, will likely increase revenue. The American Chemistry Council estimates that chemical-related industries impact more than 96.0% of all goods manufactured in the United States, so moderate industrial production will fuel demand for manufacturers. The production of tight oil is expected to remain strong.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers are expected to continue to consolidate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The chemical manufacturing process is highly energy-intensive, drawing power from electric and natural gas sources. The price of electric power will marginally decrease, which will help boost profit. Manufacturers will merge to expand their customer base to mitigate cyclical demand fluctuations.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers will be more apt to compete internationally
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As domestic and global economies grow, international trade will likely serve as a greater industry revenue source. The trade-weighted index (TWI) will decrease, reflecting a relatively weaker US dollar than leading trading partners. A weaker US dollar will make domestic goods relatively more favorable.

industry_definition: This industry produces inorganic chemicals, including titanium dioxide, chlor-alkali products and carbon black. Inorganic chemicals are mineral-based, while organic chemicals are carbon-based. Manufacturing and industrial processes use inorganic chemicals as inputs. This industry doesn't include pigments and dyes (IBISWorld report 32513) or pesticides (32532), which are inorganic chemicals.
key_trends: Energy is one of the industry's direct production costs.
Manufacturers compete on the cost to maintain profitability because all producers manufacture the same basket of products.
Manufacturers will be more apt to compete internationally. As domestic and global economies grow, international trade will serve as a greater industry revenue source.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment includes manufacturers of pulp and paper, tires, rubber, glass, textiles, fertilizer and other products.

Chemical manufacturers are the primary market for this industry. For instance, manufacturing paints, industrial coatings, laminate papers, inks and other chemical dyes use titanium dioxide. Demand for some products, like titanium dioxide and other chemicals used in dye manufacturing, fell slightly because of overcapacity in North American markets but has since recovered.

Other industries include those related to iron, steel and other metals, water treatment products, synthetic textiles, cosmetics and food producers. Demand from these industries has increased because of overcapacity in metal-related sectors, especially steel. Food processing-related industries purchase several inorganic chemicals and companies manufacture niche chemicals for their clients based on custom orders, increasing demand.

products_and_services.product_description: This category includes various inorganic chemicals, like aluminum, ammonium, chromium, magnesium, potassium, sodium and sulfur compounds. Key products include ammonium chloride, calcium carbide, chloride, hydrogen peroxide, phosphorous compounds and titanium dioxide. Titanium dioxide is a white powder pigment used in paints, coatings, plastics, papers, inks, fibers, food and cosmetics.

Catalysts are chemical substances that change the rate of a chemical reaction. Emission control catalysts can reduce emissions from cars and power plants. Industrial production declined over the past five years, decreasing demand for chemical catalysts.

The chlor-alkali process produces caustic soda or sodium hydroxide, separating sodium chloride into chlorine and sodium hydroxide. Various downstream manufacturers use the products in their processes, including pulp and paper, alumina, soap and detergents, petroleum products and chemical production.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Potassium, Sodium and Other Alkali Compounds
products_and_services.product_description: Potassium, sodium and other alkali products include sodium carbonate, sodium bicarbonate, potassium hydroxide (caustic potash) and potassium carbonate. The manufacture of biodiesel, soaps and applications use caustic potash. Still, caustic potash is more expensive to produce than caustic soda. Downstream paper pulp manufacturing industries suffered from poor performance, hindering this segment.

Carbon black, also known as acetylene black, channel black, furnace black, lamp black or thermal black, is produced from heavy petroleum products like tar. Carbon black is an essential ingredient in the production of tires, molded rubber, foam, flooring and the pigment in inks, toners, paints and plastics. According to the International Carbon Black Association, carbon black is used an estimated 90.0% in rubber applications and 9.9% as a pigment.

Chlorine has many uses. Chlorine produces about 15,000 products, including detergents, disinfectants, water treatment products, plastics, pharmaceuticals and agricultural chemicals like insecticides. Chlorine is manufactured electrolytically by the diaphragm, membrane, or mercury cell process.

Inorganic acids include sulfuric acid, hydrochloric acid and nitric acid, used in chemical-related industries to produce other chemical products, like fertilizers, plastics, synthetic textiles, paints, dyes and solvents. Acids' revenue share has decreased because of shifting downstream usage, particularly in the oil and gas and iron and steel manufacturing industries.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The rising value of the US dollar, which occurred throughout much of the period, has encouraged import increases as foreign products became relatively less expensive. A decrease in the trade-weighted index would increase the costs of imports.

Titanium dioxide and carbon black account for most imports; these products don't generate significant domestic manufacturing revenue. Less stringent environmental regulations and lower labor costs in foreign nations like China enable producers in these countries to manufacture and market products at reduced prices. The ability to produce goods abroad allows for more fierce domestic product competition.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports Rise Minimally, Keeping the Industry Afloat
international_trade_points.trade_description: The American Chemistry Council estimates that US chemical manufacturers export more than 10.0% of the world's total supply of chemicals, including caustic soda and chlorine, which have a wide range of applications in manufacturing and construction. Mexico and Canada are the main export destinations because of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), advantageous conditions and proximity.

Although the COVID-19 pandemic hampered the global economy, US inorganic chemical manufacturers could remain open while complying with new regulations, increasing demand for protective equipment and sanitizing products. China, a leading chemical manufacturer, closed many of its chemical plants early in 2021.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast grants access to the Gulf Coast, which drives export business. The Gulf Coast is an appealing location for manufacturers because of the presence of salt domes in the area, which reduces process costs. Fertilizer Manufacturing (32531), a major purchaser of acids, also has a heavy presence in this region. This region also contains many petroleum refineries and petrochemical manufacturers that purchase chemical catalysts from this industry.

This region has proximity to Canada, which is a major export destination. Companies place organic chemical facilities near consumers, raw material sources and other components of the general chemical industry.

The West contains many chemical, paper and pulp manufacturers, resulting in steady demand for inorganic chemicals. China, Japan and South Korea are major consumers of domestically manufactured inorganic chemicals and manufacturers located in the West can more easily ship goods to trading partners in Asia.

The TSCA provides the EPA with authority to require reporting, record-keeping and testing requirements, and restrictions relating to chemical substances and/or mixtures. Certain substances are documented in the EPA database and the EPA may halt the production or trade of any unsafe chemical substances.

The 1970 CAA is a comprehensive federal law regulating all sources of air emissions. It authorized the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) to protect public health and the environment.
The CWA is the principal law governing pollution control and water quality of US waterways, restoring and maintaining the nation's waters' chemical, physical and biological integrity.

The RCRA gives the EPA the authority to control hazardous waste from the cradle to the grave, including the generation, transportation, treatment, storage and disposal of hazardous waste. The RCRA also set forth a framework for managing non-hazardous solid wastes.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The inorganic chemicals industry is in the decline life cycle stage, increasing barriers to entry.
Capital remains central to inorganic chemical manufacturing, driven by significant investment in automation, enabling products to be mass-produced.

basis_points.basis_title: Pricing as primary basis of competition
basis_points.basis_description: Given the commoditized nature of inorganic chemicals, prices are the primary basis of competition. Pricing connects to energy and raw material prices, like natural gas and production efficiency.

Manufacturers face competitive pressure from substitute products. For example, soda ash manufacturers are increasingly competing with manufacturers of glass substitutes (e.g. plastic or recycled glass).

concentration_points.concentration_description: Inorganic chemical manufacturing is highly fragmented. The top four manufacturers in the industry generate less than 40.0% of revenue.
Like other capital- and resource-intensive manufacturing sectors, inorganic chemical manufacturing contains a diverse range of companies based on production capability.

Manufacturers have merged to jointly pursue new technology and products, like more energy-efficient machinery and chemicals. Concentration has risen as manufacturers have merged and acquired several other companies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT (R&D) ACCOUNTS FOR THE MAJORITY OF OTHER COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs, which include research and development expenses, have climbed over the past five years to 2024. Manufacturers that can afford to hire top research personnel and invest resources into R&D can obtain unique technological advantages.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital remains central to inorganic chemical manufacturing, driven by significant investment in automation, enabling products to be mass-produced.

The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for inorganic chemicals is cyclical and dependent on the prevailing macroeconomic environment. Revenue is susceptible to consumer spending changes. Global industrial activity fluctuations can also have severe implications for revenue growth.

The Russian invasion of Ukraine and the higher interest rates as a result of fighting inflation have hurt manufacturing activity, supply chains and limited consumer spending growth, putting downward pressure on industry revenue.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by imports?
FAQs.answer: Imports have increased over the past five years. Import's share of total domestic demand has increased and is still high in this industry.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy? How did you perform during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: As the industry manufactures a broad array of chemicals, revenue, especially for bigger operators comes from diversified sources.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Volatile but decreasing crude oil prices have helped operators in the industry decrease purchase costs and increase profitability. During 2020, the world price of crude oil declined amid the pandemic.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Major players have large international facilities and have expanded them recently.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs have increased on account for the need of highly-skilled labor force in the production process.

FAQs.question: Do you use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of your company's manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: Level of technology innovation in the industry is high. Technology has been integrated into all levels of the industry's day-to-day operations, from actual production to inventory management.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Recent regulatory changes have increased costs but profitability has not been impacted.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers in the industry have a large number of pending litigation on account of environmental norms being flouted.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Overall, industry profit has been volatile due to the pandemic and the industry showing signs of recovery.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Capital intensity in the industry is moderate and purchase of new equipment can cost a significant amount of money.

FAQs.question: Do you have key contracts with raw material providers? How do you negotiate favorable supply contracts?
FAQs.answer: Access to competitively priced raw materials is vital to remaining competitive. Manufacturers should maintain good relations with upstream suppliers to ensure access to raw materials regardless of economic conditions.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? How can you expand your operations?
FAQs.answer: Reducing average costs by spreading fixed costs over larger production volumes enables inorganic chemical manufacturers to be more competitive. These lower per-unit costs enable industry producers to widen profit margins without raising prices.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques? How quickly can you implement these new technologies?
FAQs.answer: With a high level of competition within the industry and increased exposure to international competition, adequate technology that lowers manufacturing costs is essential for competing with other US manufacturers and imports.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor trends in the industrial production index? What does an increase in the IPI mean for your company's revenue?
FAQs.answer: Since manufacturers make up a significant portion of this industry's total market, an increase in the IPI will likely correlate with increased demand for industry products.

FAQs.question: In what ways will your business benefit from the expected increase in consumer spending? How can you generate revenue when consumer spending declines?
FAQs.answer: The Plastic and Resin Manufacturing industry purchases inorganic chemicals to manufacture products, such as plastic bags, films, sheets and bottles.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in housing starts? How much of your revenue comes from residential construction?
FAQs.answer: As more houses are built, demand for construction products made from industry chemicals will increase, boosting industry revenue. Fortunately, housing starts surged amid the pandemic.
